author: Emma Blake
title: How to save money on haircuts
text:
HAIRCUTS are a regular expense (for most of us anyway) but no matter your style, gender or colour preference there’s always a way to shave a few bucks off your barber’s bill.
Women heading to the hairdresser for a snip, style and shade usually end up paying a lot more than men to look sharp on top.
But with the fashion for barber shops on the rise some men are paying top dollar for a cut.
Fi Mason, a barber specialist at The Barber Shop says the a fashion for all things retro right now, including barber shops, is seeing more opening up especially in inner city areas.
The salon charges $50 for a haircut and $40 for a traditional hot towel shave but, with a bar out the back, it also offers beer and even whiskey cocktails while you’re being groomed.
For most, however, the average local barber will provide men, and often kids, with a basic cut for $10 to $20 depending on the location.
And there’s no reason why women who have a simple, short cut can’t go to one of these shops for a trim.
MONEYSAVERHQ'S ULTIMATE GUIDE TO SAVING MONEY
Mobile hairdresser Don Steele cuts Laila Gibson’s hair as her family looks on. Source: News Limited
Otherwise, if you want a more complex style, have time to spare or are prepared to be a bit adventurous, why not head to a local hairdressing college, TAFE or school.
They are always looking for people who are happy to provide students with experience for a fraction of the cost of a fully qualified stylist.
Mobile hairdressers who come to you door can also be cheaper than many salons.
Don Steele used to have a salon in rural Victoria but gave it away and decided to take his tools to the customers rather than the other way around.
“I’m actually cheaper than the average hairdresser because my overheads are a lot lower; no shop rental, rates, power bills or staff.”.
Otherwise look out for deals from new salons opening in your area, search online for deals and be prepared to shop around.
Or if you are happy to let your hair hang a bit longer than usually, spread out the time between snips. Having a $20 cut every eight weeks instead of every four could save you $43 — or more than two cuts — every year.
